ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about the anatomy of different vertebrates, specifically muscle plan, body plan, cranial nerves, internal anatomy, and bones.

Understanding form and function of organisms, evolutionary relationship between vertebrates, and the many homologous structures in vertebrate bodies, in addition to a broad knowledge of various bodies.
The course complemented the lecture very well. It provided a visual and physical experience that reinforced the material learned in lecture.

Learned how to compare vertebrate anatomical structures across taxa and identify them in specimens
Learned the forms and functions of many anatomical structures
I learned a lot of really cool lab dissection skills and anatomical information about vertebrates. In fact, our discussion went beyond anatomy to also include habitat and function.
Anatomical features of and differences among the taxa we studied and specimens provided, considered their functional and evolutionary significance

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: There was very little instruction regarding the actual dissection part of the class. As someone who had never done any formal anatomical dissections before, I would have appreciated a bit more formal guidance.
I really liked the final practical style. It could be improved by having lab reports instead of practicals.
The instructor and TAs were always present and engaging with insightful answers and assistance

Strengths: The course covers a lot of ground and has many fascinating dissections
Weaknesses: While this wasn't really in the control of the instruction team, the dissections were often very difficult to carry out in the time we had/with the specimens we had to the level of quality where we would be able to see the structures we were meant to see. This meant that for the lab practical, we were often trying to answer questions based on things we hadn't seen ourselves or had seen only very roughly. There was also almost no anatomical introduction to the dissection labs beyond diagrams and lists of terms; I ended up having to figure out a lot of the homologies, functions, and naming conventions by myself through Googling while reading my notes before the final. I think more in-depth lab handouts with explanations of function/homology, or longer pre-lab discussions from Professor Moyer, would have done wonders in helping us appreciate what we were seeing.

Strengths: very patient and helpful teaching team. We would ask so many questions during lab and they were always happy to help.

Weaknesses: studying for and taking the exams is very difficult. Its hard to transfer everything from in person dissections to photos, study from these photos, and then transfer this knowledge to in person specimen that are different from the ones we originally dissected.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! It's a very interesting and enjoyable lab!
This course is fundamental for a "practical" understanding of biology and a necessity for premed students
I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone taking the lecture as well

A biology lab with real specimens is a wonderful experience that many people probably haven't had, and this lab certainly gives a great selection of such experiences. Do be prepared: there is somewhat of a learning curve in figuring out how to study for the practicals. The 50-55 questions on the two practicals, with at least 80% of them having 1-word answers, made up 50% of our grade, so one question missed could mean 1% down from the final, uncurved grade. Outside of that quirk of the grading, though, the class was a lot of fun and I'd highly recommend it to anyone taking the comparative anatomy course (E&EB 290)
Yes if you need to take it. Exams are difficult, so Id you just want to dissect some vertebrates and learn about them for fun, maybe consider credit/d/fail!
